Ah, a fresh face in the trade, are we? You’ve got the eyes of a street cat—always watching, always calculating. That’s good. But eyes alone won’t get you far. If you want to walk away clean, you’ve got to think like a ghost. Here’s what I’d tell you—rules I’ve learned the hard way, and ones I’ve never broken.

**1. Patience is your best tool.**  
Rushing gets you caught. I’ve seen too many novices who think speed is everything. No. A heist is a chess match. You don’t make a move until you’ve studied the board. Wait for the right moment. Let the guards grow comfortable. Let the system grow complacent. That’s when you strike.

**2. Know your target inside and out.**  
I spend weeks—sometimes months—on reconnaissance. Blueprints, security rotations, blind spots, camera angles, guard routines. I even know the kind of coffee the night shift drinks and when they take their smoke breaks. The more you know, the less you have to improvise. And improvisation is where mistakes are born.

**3. Leave no trace, take no risks.**  
You’re not a vandal. You’re not a looter. You’re a surgeon. You cut in, you take what you came for, and you vanish without a scar. Wear gloves, clean up fibers, don’t touch anything that doesn’t serve you. I use a dry erase marker for fingerprints—just wipe it off. If you can’t make it look like it was never there, you’re not ready.

**4. Use the environment to your advantage.**  
Lighting, weather, time of day—these are your allies. A stormy night is perfect for masking your approach. A malfunctioning camera? That’s your window. A delivery truck parking outside? That’s your cover. The world is full of distractions. Learn to use them.
